DROPDOWN.text: Sites and tools to support accessibility and usability, to ensure promotion good practices and improve the experience of using digital services.

accessibility.text: Dissemination, sharing and promotion of best accessibility practices for web content and mobile applications.
accessibility.link1: DL n.º 83/2018 - accessibility of the web and mobile applications

usability.text: Resources, tools and good practices to improve the usability and experience of using digital services.

badge.text: Seal of excellence that rewards good accessibility and usability practices on public service websites.

HOME_PAGE.header: Få en tilgjengelighetsrapport ved hjelp av en av følgende metoder
HOME_PAGE.intro_text: Access our web accessibility practice (WCAG 2.1) assessor here. Obtain an accessibility report using one of the following methods:
HOME_PAGE.url_error: Skriv inn en gyldig url. F.eks http://www.google.com

messages.invalid_url: Den oppgitte url-adressen er ugyldig eller eksisterer ikke

metadata.validator: We couldn't contact the W3C html markup validator

results.title: Evaluering
results.subtitle: praksis oppdaget, som kan klassifiseres etter:

MISC.unexpected_error: En uventet feil har oppstått. Prøv igjen senere.
MISC.error_contact: Hvis problemet vedvarer, vennligst kontakt oss...

_404.title: Feilkode 404
_404.description: Siden du prøvde å nå eksisterer ikke.

messages.data_error: Det har oppstått en feil under forsøket på å hente inn brukerdata
messages.data_table_error: En feil har oppstått ved forsøk på å laste datatabellen

ELEMS.aAdjacentSame: Like linker fører til samme destinasjon.
ELEMS.aImgAltNo: Links where the only content is an image with null alt or no caption
ELEMS.aSameText: Links with the same text that point to different destinations
ELEMS.aSkipFirst: Link to skip to main content
ELEMS.aTitleMatch: Links with the same text in content and title attribute
ELEMS.aGroupNo: Group of 10 or more links non-grouped by structural elements
ELEMS.area: Active Zones of an Image Map
ELEMS.colorContrast: Color combinations with a contrast ratio less than 3: 1
ELEMS.colorFgBgNo: CSS rules in which the background color and/or letter color are not specified simultaneously
ELEMS.fontAbsVal: Font sizes defined in absolute units of measure
ELEMS.fontHtml: Elements and Attributes (X) HTML to format the Text of pages (eg basefont, font, link, and alink)
ELEMS.frameDtdNo: Document frameset with incorrect or missing doctype
ELEMS.img: Images with equivalent alternative in text
ELEMS.imgAltNo: Images without equivalent alternative in text
ELEMS.inputIdTitleNo: Form controls without label [label] associated and without the attribute title
ELEMS.inputLabel: Form controls that have explicitly associated a label (label)
ELEMS.label: Elements label
ELEMS.layoutAttr: (X)HTML attributes to format page layout (eg align, hspace and bgcolor)
ELEMS.layoutElem: (X)HTML elements to format page layout (eg blink and center)
ELEMS.layoutFixed: Elements with absolute values in CSS property "width"
ELEMS.liNoList: List items used outside of lists
ELEMS.newWinOnLoad: New window once the page loads
ELEMS.tableCaptionSummary: Tables with the same text in the caption element and the summary attribute
ELEMS.tableComplexError: Complex data tables without the headers attribute in the data cells
ELEMS.tableLayoutCaption: Tables without headers cells, but with the caption element
ELEMS.titleChars: Title with non-textual string (probably ASCII art)
ELEMS.titleLong: Number of characters in the title element
ELEMS.titleSame: Repeated page title on other pages of the site
ELEMS.valueAbsCss: Absolute units of measure in CSS
ELEMS.valueRelCss: Relative units of measure in CSS

TECHS.C19: Specifying Left OR Right Alignment in CSS
TECHS.C22: Use CSS to control the visual presentation of text
TECHS.C24: Use percentage values in CSS for box sizes
TECHS.C9: Use CSS to include decorative images
TECHS.F16: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.2 due to the inclusion of content on the move, where the movement is not essential to the activity, without also including a mechanism to pause and restart the content
TECHS.F17: Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 and 4.1.1 due to insufficient information in the DOM to determine one-to-one relationships (eg between tags with the same id) in HTML
TECHS.F24: Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.3, 1.4.6 and 1.4.8 due to specifying foreground colors without specifying background colors and vice versa
TECHS.F25: Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.2 because the title of a Web page does not identify the contents
TECHS.F30: Failure of Success Criteria 1.1.1 and 1.2.1 due to the use of text alternatives that are not alternatives (eg, file names or placeholder text)
TECHS.F4: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.2 due to the use of text-decoration
TECHS.F40: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.1 and 2.2.4 due to the use of a redirect goal with a time limit
TECHS.F41: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.1, 2.2.4, and 3.2.5 due to the use of a meta refresh with a timeout exceeded
TECHS.F46: Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 due to use of th elements, caption elements, or non-empty summary attributes in schema tables
TECHS.F47: Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.2 due to the use of the blink element
TECHS.F49: Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.2 due to the use of an HTML schema table that does not make sense when linearized
TECHS.F52: Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.1 due to the presentation of a new window as soon as a new page is loaded
TECHS.F54: Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.1 due to use only of event handlers specific to the pointing device (including gestures) for a function
TECHS.F55: Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.1, 2.4.7 and 3.2.1 due to using script to remove focus when focus is received
TECHS.F59: Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.2 due to using script to make a div or a span in an HTML user interface control
TECHS.F65: Failure of Success Criterion 1.1.1 due to omission of the alt attribute in img elements, area elements, and input elements of type "image"
TECHS.F68: Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 and 4.1.2 due to association of label controls and user interface that are not programmatically determinable
TECHS.F77: Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.1 due to duplication of values of type ID
TECHS.F84: Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.9 due to the use of a non-specific link, such as "click here" or "more" without a mechanism to change link text to specific text
TECHS.F88: Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.8 due to the use of justified text (aligned to the left and right margins)
TECHS.F89: Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.4, 2.4.9 and 4.1.2 due to the use of null alt in an image where the image is the only content in a link
TECHS.G1: Add a link at the top of each page to directly access the main content area
TECHS.G102: Provide the full definition or explanation of an abbreviation
TECHS.G115: Use semantic elements to mark structure
TECHS.G123: Add a link at the beginning of a block of repeated content to directly access the end of the block
TECHS.G125: Provide links to navigate to related Web pages
TECHS.G140: Separate information and presentation structure to allow different presentations
TECHS.G145: Ensure a contrast ratio of at least 3
TECHS.G162: Placing labels to increase the predictability of relationships
TECHS.G88: Provide descriptive titles for web pages
TECHS.H2: Combine the adjacent image and text links for the same resource
TECHS.H24: Provide text alternatives to the image area area elements
TECHS.H25: Provide a title using the title element
TECHS.H27: Providing alternatives in text and non-text format for object
TECHS.H33: Providing add-ins to link text with the title attribute
TECHS.H35: Providing text alternatives in applet elements
TECHS.H36: Use alt attributes in images used as Submit buttons
TECHS.H37: Use alt attributes in img elements
TECHS.H39: Use caption elements to associate titles with data tables
TECHS.H43: Use the id and headers attributes to associate data cells with header cells in data tables
TECHS.H44: Using label elements to associate text labels with form controls
TECHS.H48: Use ol, ul and dl for lists
TECHS.H51: Use table marking to present information arranged in tables
TECHS.H57: Use language attributes in html element
TECHS.H59: Use the link element and navigation tools
TECHS.H63: Use the scope attribute to associate header cells with data cells in data tables
TECHS.H64: Using the title attribute of the frame and the iframe elements
TECHS.H65: Use the title attribute to identify form controls when the label element can not be used
TECHS.H71: Provide a description for groups of form controls using fieldset and legend elements
TECHS.H73: Use the summary attribute of the table element to provide an overview of the data tables
TECHS.SCR20: Using the keyboard and other device-specific functions

TXT_TECHNIQUES.C12: When the text size is expressed in absolute units there are browsers that will have difficulty in zoom the text.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C19: Some persons with low vision and persons with cognitive impairments have big difficulty in dealing with the text blocks when are justified.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C21: Many people with cognitive disability have difficulty to follow the text lines when the text has a simple spacement. To use a spacement between 1,5 and 2, will help them when skipping lines.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C22: This practice is obsolete. Instead of it, you should use the CSS to control the visual text presentation. When this error occurs is because you are using inside the <body> element of the webpage, the elements: b, basefont, font, i, s, strike, u, or the attributes: text, vlink, alink, link.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C24: Zoom 200% the screen and check that all the content is visible without the need to make horizontal scannings
TXT_TECHNIQUES.C9: The use of null or empty alternative texts in HTML is a common practice for images classified as decorative. However, all images classified as decorative must be affixed via CSS and not via HTML.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F16: It is important that the user has control of the content in movement, namely that can stop it.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F17: The accesskey attributes need to obtain unique values, otherwise the result can be irregular from one technology to another one.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F24: There is no need that the font colour and the background colour be defined in the same CSS rule but is recommended. This is the only way to guarantee that the user gets the desired contrast.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F25: It is defined as a failure condition always that a webpage has a title equal to a title from other webpage in the same website. Each page should have a unique title which identifies the contents purpose.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F30: In the <code>alt</ code> attribute of the <code>img</ code> element I found the image file name or one of the following values: "img", "image", "spacer", "space", "picture ", "alt", "alttext", "imagen", "imagem", "foto", "photo", or one of the following image file extensions .jpg, .jpeg, .gif, .png. None of the elements referred above serves as an alternative textual equivalent.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F4: Some user groups, particularly those who have disturbs that cause attention deficit, find in the shinning content distraction elements, making dificult the concentration capacity in the other parts of the webpage.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F40: The value "refresh" should be used carefully, as it takes the control of a page away from the user.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F41: The value "refresh" should be used carefully, as it takes the control of a page away from the user.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F46: I suspect that I might find data tables which is missing headings identification. Otherwise, it could be layout tables and in this case have a title, which you must remove.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F47: Some user groups, particularly those who have disturbs that cause attention deficit, find in the shinning content distraction elements, making difficult the concentration capacity in the other parts of the webpage.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F49: When linearized the tables check if the content is perceptible.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F54: Check if you use the event manipulators onDblClick e/ou onMouseMove. When using event manipulators which depend on mouses, or "depending on pointing devices", the users who need to use the keyboard or other alternative input devices that work as emulated keyboards, will be unable to access.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F55: Scroll the edition fields and check if the focus is inhibited by programation techniques. When removing the focus of the content, this becomes no longer operable by those who use only keyboard to navigate.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F59: The generic elements as <div> and <span> don't have a predefined role. When using these generic elements to create the user interface controls in HTML, the Assistive Technologies don't have enogh information to describe and interact with the controls, namely if doesn't define a "role" with ARIA techniques.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F65: Verify if the alternative textual equivalent found in the graphic buttons serves the equal information or function performed by the graphic button on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F68: It isn't mandatory to exist always an explicit relation between the edition fields (<input>) and the labels (<label>) but it always be useful to the Assistive Technologies that this relation be established. Therefore, each <label> element must have the for attribute.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F77: Duplicates ids attributes can cause undesirable behaviors. The ids are content uniques identifiers and that's why are unrepeatable. They can serve to point content or define relations between content parts.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F84: It is important that the users be able to determine the link purpose and destiny without the need to access to content where is located. There are users whose Assistive Technologies provide them all the webpage links presented in list, without any content.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F88: Some persons with low vision and persons with cognitive impairements have big difficulty in dealing with the text blocks when are justified.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.F89: This fail occurs always that a link is composed by an image and that image has an empty nature as alternative textual equivalent - I suspect that the Assistive Technologies' users don't know their destiny or purpose, or may even don't realize the existence of the link.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G1: Make available at the top of the webpage a link that allows skipping directly to the main content of the webpage. This link facilitates the navigation to many users, namely those who use scanning selection software. These users use vision to read information so the links must be always visible ou become visible when receiving the focus.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G102: Mark the abbreviations and/or acronyms with the respective extension. In the HTML5 case it is used the <code>abbr</code> element to mark abbreviations or acronyms. For instance: <abbr title="Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia">FCT</abbr>
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G115: With the appearance of the CSS all the HTML elements used to control styles of the webpages became obsolete. Elements as: b, big, blink, center, font, i, s, strike, u became obsolete - use CSS to replace them.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G123: Check if the links that I found provide the most suitable skips to the content; if  they are  always visible or if become visible when receiving focus by keyboard.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G125: The WWW nature is to provide links on webpages to other related webpages. It is this that allow to users navigate information. One webpage without links is strange, at first sight!
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G130: The headers must be descriptive but at the same time brief. Its content, in any situation, should never be null - it is what's happening in this case.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G134: The CSS errors are one of the causes of the webpages be presented in a inconsistent way in the different browsers. To meet a specification and to validate the syntax according to that specification enhances the consistency and the correct interpretation from the technologies, namely the Assistive Technologies.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G140: With the appearance of the CSS all the HTML attributes used to control styles of the webpages became obsolete. Attributes as: align, hspace, vspace, color, face, size (in the elements basefont, font), text, link, alink, vlink, bgcolor, background  became obsolete - use CSS to replace them.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G141: The web pages must be marked with a hierarchical structure of headers and subheadings. Each page should have, at least, one header level 1. The level 2 should mark the sections and the level 3 the subsections of these. This same logic must be applied until to the subsections of level 6.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G145: According to the success criteria 1.4.3, the ratio 3 to 1 corresponds to the minimum for text "in large size" (18pt or 14 pt bold, or larger). I remind that for the size of normal font the minimum ratio is 4,5 to 1.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G146: Zoom 200% the screen and check that all the content is visible without the need to make horizontal scannings.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G162: The labels must be positioned just before the fields. The labels to the fields of checkbox list types and the radio buttons type should be positioned just after the fields.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G88: The <title> of each webpage should: (1) identify the page subject; (2) make sense when readable out of context; (3) be short.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.G90: You must ensure that the javascript events are activated not only by mouse but also by keyboard. Check the pairs of manipulators: mousedown/keydown, mouseup/keyup, mouseover/focus, mouseout/blur. Note: The AccessMonitor doesn't check the pair onclick / onkeypress because considers that the browsers support the onclick also when using only the keyboard. This test is classified correct only when there aren't errors in the other tests of checked manipulators.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H2: When adjacent links point to exactly the same resource, we can put them together in just one link. Usually, in these situations, we have the visual sensation of having one single link but in case of some Assistive Technologies' users they emerge duplicates, what can be confusing.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H24: Check if the alternative textual equivalent that exists in the active areas in the images map serves information ou has the function equal to the one performed by the image map on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H25: Take note that the <title> element should only appear once in the webpage.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H27: Always that you use an <object> element, make available the alternative textual equivalent in the element body.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H32: After being filled, it is necessary to submit the form data to the server. This is the function of the submit button.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H33: The title attribute is used to provide additional information to that one existent in the text link. The attribute title and the text of the link should be sufficient to understand the link purpose.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H35: Each applet element should contain one alternative textual equivalent in its body and a textual equivalent in its alt attribute. It is important using both mechanisms since the user agents support in an inconsistent way the alt attribute and the alternative text positioned in the body of <applet>.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H36: The <input> element is used to create many types of form controls. Despite of the DTD of HTML and XHTML allow the use of alt attribute in all its elements, the alt attribute should be used, in case of the <input> element, only in the graphical buttons.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H37: Verify if the alternative textual equivalent found in the images serves the equal information or function performed by the image on the page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H39: I suspect that I might find data tables which is missing title identification <caption>.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H42: The web pages must be marked with a hierarchical structure of headers and subheadings. Each page should have, at least, one header level 1. The level 2 should mark the sections and the level 3 the subsections of these. This same logic must be applied until to the subsections of level 6.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H43: In complex data tables (with headings in various rows) it is important to associate explicitly the data cells to the various headings which contextualize them. That association is done with the headers attribute.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H44: The <label> elements associated to the <input> elements allow the Assistive Technologies users to identify the label that contextualize an edition field. The explicit association is done by the pair of id and dor attributes, respectively, from the <input> and <label> elements.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H45: The longdesc attribute must be composed by an URL that points the localization where its found the long description - it can be to other page or a bookmark to a page.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H46: When we use the <embed> element we have to make available an alternative textual equivalent <noembed>. The element <noembed> is only showed if the <embed> element is not supported.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H48: If the content that I identified is, in fact, a list of options then use the correct structural marking (i.e. <ul>, <ol>).
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H51: Despite the WCAG do not prohibit the use of layout tables it is recommended not to use them. If the tables used contain data then mark the heading cells conveniently.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H57: The HTML just has the lang attribute. The XHTML 1.1 just allows the xml:lang. The XHTML 1.0 (as a transitional measure) allows both attributes. The XHTML served as text/html uses the lang and xml:lang attributes of the html element.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H59: Check if in each of the <link> elements, that exist in the <head> of the webpage, the href points to an apropriated resource.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H63: The scope attribute identifies if a cell constitutes a heading of a line, of a column, of a group of lines or of a group of columns. The values row, col, rowgroup and colgroup identify respectively the values that the scope may assume.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H64: The frames are windows where is possible to see the content coming from another server. It is important to identify conveniently those frames. Use the title attribute to that purpose!
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H65: To fill the edition fields, the users need that those be identified. It can be an explicit identification (marked in the code) or implicit (usually derived from the relative position). Explicitly it can be done by the <label> element or by the title attribute of the <input> element.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H71: The form controls can be grouped, according its purpose, through the <fieldset> element. The first element inside of <fieldset> should be the <legend>, which acts as label or description to the grouping.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H73: I suspect that I might find data tables which content is in <caption> element is the same in the summary attribute.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H88: The DTD defines the version of HTML grammar that is being used on the webpage. Its non existence make the users agents enter in a guess process of the best way to interpret the code. This makes to increase the probability of the inconsistency in the way the content is presented.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.SCR20: You must ensure that the javascript events are activated not only by mouse but also by keyboard. Check the pairs of manipulators: mousedown/keydown, mouseup/keyup, mouseover/focus, mouseout/blur. Note: The AccessMonitor doesn't check the pair onclick / onkeypress because considers that the browsers support the onclick also when using only the keyboard.
TXT_TECHNIQUES.H50: To group related links to each other is a facilitating action of navigation. To group, we can use lists - <ul>; <ol> - or the <map> element usual in the marking of images map.
